(e) Schematics of the NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathode with thermal-triggered flame-retardant properties for Li-S batteries. At elevated operating temperature NCF-MXene-APP acts as an efficient LiPS diverter, and in case of thermal runaway of the batteries, the NCF-MXene-APP will form an effective heat and oxygen barrier to prevent the propagation of fire. Flame-retardant ammonium polyphosphate/MXene decorated carbon foam materials as polysulfide traps for fire-safe and stable lithium-sulfur batteries Yang Li a Yong-Cheng Zhu c Sowjanya Vallem a Man Li a Seunghyun Song a Tao Chen d Long-Cheng Tang b ⁎ Joonho Bae a ⁎ a Department of Physics, Gachon University, Seongnam-si, Gyeonggi-do 13120, South Korea Department of Physics Gachon University Seongnam-si Gyeonggi-do 13120 South Korea Department of Physics, Gachon University, Seongnam-si, Gyeonggi-do 13120, South Korea b Key Laboratory of Organosilicon Chemistry and Material Technology of Ministry of Education, College of Material, Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hangzhou Normal University, Hangzhou 311121, Zhejiang, China Key Laboratory of Organosilicon Chemistry and Material Technology of Ministry of Education College of Material, Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hangzhou Normal University Hangzhou Zhejiang 311121 China Key Laboratory of Organosilicon Chemistry and Material Technology of Ministry of Education, College of Material, Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hangzhou Normal University, Hangzhou 311121, Zhejiang, China c Key laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Key laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education) College of Chemistry Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China Key laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China d School of Materials Engineering, Changzhou Vocational Institute of Industry Technology, Changzhou 213164, Jiangsu, China School of Materials Engineering Changzhou Vocational Institute of Industry Technology Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 China School of Materials Engineering, Changzhou Vocational Institute of Industry Technology, Changzhou 213164, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract MXene and ammonium polyphosphate were employed to decorate nitrogen-doped carbon foam and the as-prepared flame-retardant NCF-MXene-APP composites with strong polysulfide anchoring can serve as ideal electrodes for safe and high-performance Li-S batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are one of the most promising modern-day energy supply systems because of their high theoretical energy density and low cost. However, the development of high-energy density Li-S batteries with high loading of flammable sulfur faces the challenges of electrochemical performance degradation owing to the shuttle effect and safety issues related to fire or explosion accidents. In this work, we report a three-dimensional (3D) conductive nitrogen-doped carbon foam supported electrostatic self-assembled MXene-ammonium polyphosphate (NCF-MXene-APP) layer as a heat-resistant, thermally-insulated, flame-retardant, and freestanding host for Li-S batteries with a facile and cost-effective synthesis method. Consequently, through the use of NCF-MXene-APP hosts that strongly anchor polysulfides, the Li-S batteries demonstrate outstanding electrochemical properties, including a high initial discharge capacity of 1191.6 mA h g−1, excellent rate capacity of 755.0 mA h g−1 at 1 C, and long-term cycling stability with an extremely low-capacity decay rate of 0.12% per cycle at 2 C. More importantly, these batteries can continue to operate reliably under high temperature or flame attack conditions. Thus, this study provides valuable insights into the design of safe high-performance Li-S batteries. Keywords Flame-retardant MXene Ammonium polyphosphate Safety Lithium-sulfur battery 1 Introduction The increasing demand for electric vehicles, portable electronics, and renewable energy storage systems has created a need for battery technologies with higher energy densities than traditional lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries [1–5]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have gained considerable attention as a promising next-generation high-energy battery system owing to their high theoretical energy density (2500 W h kg−1), which is approximately five times higher than that of state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries [6–10]. Moreover, the abundance, low cost, and environmentally benign nature of sulfur make it advantageous for the commercialization of Li-S batteries [11–14]. However, the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries is hindered by the inherent insulating characteristics of sulfur and the adverse polysulfide shuttling effect, resulting in operational instability [15–18]. In addition, to fully utilize the benefits of high theoretical energy density, there is an urgent need for Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading [19–21]. Nevertheless, the higher loading of flammable sulfur in Li-S batteries raises safety concerns [22,23]. The rational design of sulfur cathodes remains a challenge for simultaneously improving the electrochemical performance and safety of commercially feasible Li-S batteries. Extensive research efforts have focused on improving the conductivity of intermediate sulfides and controlling the formation of polysulfides by physically confining sulfur within various porous structures of carbon materials [24–28]. However, the weak interactions between nonpolar carbon materials and polar polysulfides were ineffective in improving the long-term cycling stability of sulfur cathodes, particularly in high-loading battery designs [29–32]. Recently, MXene, a two-dimensional (2D) layered transition metal carbide and nitride, or carbonitride material, with tunable polar functional groups, exceptional metallic conductivity, large specific surface area, and versatile functionality, has offered immense possibilities for the development of viable Li-S battery cathodes [33–35]. The Ti atoms on MXene sheet surfaces should be valued due to their ability to improve the chemisorption of polysulfides through the formation of Lewis acid-base interactions between MXene and lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), as well as excellent catalytic conversion effect for polysulfides [36–39]. More importantly, the inherent flame retardancy of MXene made it a promising alternative for use as nanofillers or nanocoating materials to prepare fire-safe composites [40,41]. For example, Wu et al. reported the development of silane modified MXene and polybenzazole nanocomposite aerogels with high flame resistance and thermal stability [42]. In particular, incorporating flame-retardant MXene in the fabrication of battery components was expected to improve the fire-safety of batteries [43,44]. In a previous study, we successfully developed multifunctional interlayers for Li-S batteries by co-assembling deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) molecules with carbon nanotube (CNT)/MXene networks that enabled safe battery operation at high temperatures [45]. However, the MXene nanosheets tended to readily undergo self-restacking due to Van der Waals forces, potentially leading to adverse effects on their intrinsic performance and the access of electrolyte ions [46–48]. In this case, developing efficient strategies to mitigate self-restacking while simultaneously enhancing the properties of MXenes is highly desired. Incorporating materials with specific structures as intercalants is considered to be a promising strategy [49–51]. Ammonium polyphosphate (APP), as an affordable water-soluble inorganic polymer rich in both phosphorus and nitrogen, serves as a source of acid and gas, exhibiting excellent fire-retardant properties, which can be used either independently as a flame retardant or in synergy with other flame retardants [52]. More importantly, APP has been considered as an effective medium for assisting in the assembly of MXene nanosheets [53]. Employing a three-dimensional (3D) network architecture for MXene effectively mitigated sheet stacking and agglomeration while simultaneously enabling high active material loading [54–56]. Overall, considering the criteria for high-performance and high-safe Li-S battery cathodes, MXene-based flame-retardant composites with high electrical conductivities, 3D porous structures, and chemisorption centers for polysulfides may be an excellent choice. In this work, we present a facile method to fabricate a heat-resistant, flame-retardant, and self-supported NCF-MXene-APP composite for Li-S battery hosts. In this design, the 3D porous nitrogen-doped carbon foam (NCF) framework wrapped with electrostatic self-assembled MXene/APP can not only provide an improvement in the physicochemical adsorption and conversion of polysulfides, but also suppress the combustion behavior of the flammable sulfur active materials. Thus, the as-prepared NCF-MXene-APP composite contributes significantly to achieving an excellent electrochemical energy storage capacity and enhancing the safety of Li-S batteries even under high sulfur loading conditions. Furthermore, detailed discussions on the underlying mechanism have been conducted based on comprehensive analysis and comparative experiments. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Ti3AlC2 precursors and APP particles were purchased from 11 Technology Co. Ltd., China, and Jinan Enter Chemical Co. Ltd., China, respectively. Commercial melamine foam (MF) was provided by SINOYQX Co. Ltd., China. Other chemicals and reagents including lithium fluoride (LiF, ≥98 wt%), concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl, 35 wt%), ethanol, and sublimed sulfur were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Synthesis of an MXene-APP solution First, Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets were synthesized by applying LiF/HCl-based etching and liquid-phase exfoliation techniques to a high-purity MAX (Ti3AlC2) phase precursor similar to our previous work [45]. The morphological structures are shown in Fig. S1. Afterward, a certain amount of APP powder was dispersed in the MXene aqueous solution (10 mg mL−1) with magnetic stirring for 60 min until a homogeneous mixture suspension was formed. The weight ratio of APP to MXene sheets in the suspension was approximately 1:2. 2.3 Synthesis of an nitrogen-doped carbon foam According to a typical preparation method reported previously, NCF was fabricated by the simple carbonization of a commercial MF [57]. In brief, the MF with a size of approximately 10 cm × 4 cm × 0.7 cm was washed with ethanol and deionized water, and dried overnight at 60 °C. Then, the MF was placed in a tubular furnace and annealed at 800 °C for 2 h under an argon (Ar) atmosphere to obtain the carbonized NCF. 2.4 Synthesis of an NCF-MXene-APP composite host To fabricate the NCF-MXene-APP composite host, the obtained NCF was fully dipped in the MXene-APP mixed solution and dried overnight in a vacuum oven at a fixed temperature of 60 °C. Finally, the sample was cut into a circle with a diameter of 1 cm, which was used as the cathode substrate. The MXene-APP content in the NCF-MXene-APP composite was calculated as approximately 38.39 wt% (Fig. S2). For comparison, the NCF-MXene composite host was fabricated according to the same procedure without the addition of APP. The NCF host was prepared by heat treatment under the same conditions and using the same procedure. The diameter of the sulfur cathodes in Li-S batteries is 1 cm. All samples were placed in a glove box for further use (Fig. S3). 2.5 Synthesis of a polysulfide catholyte A dispersion of the polysulfide catholyte was prepared according to a previously reported method [58]. First, a blank electrolyte was obtained by dissolving 1 M LiN(CF3SO2)2 (LiTFSI) and 1 wt% LiNO3 in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (1:1 volume ratio). Afterward, the sublimed sulfur was directly reacted overnight with Li2S (5:1 molar ratio) in the resultant electrolyte with stirring at 60 °C to form the 0.5 M Li2S6 catholyte. All processes were conducted in an Ar-filled glove box. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements CR2032 coin cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box using the as-prepared NCF-MXene-APP cathode substrate with the dropwise addition of the polysulfide catholyte, lithium metal, polypropylene film (Celgard 2500), and 1 M LiTFSI in 1:1 (v/v) DOL:DME and 1 wt% LiNO3 solution as the cathode, anode, separator, and electrolyte, respectively. The sulfur loading was controlled at approximately 3.2, 5.1, and 6.4 mg cm−2 by adjusting the amount of catholyte. The 3.2 mg cm−2 NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 composite showed approximately 67.5% sulfur loading by thermogravimetric analysis (as shown in Fig. S4). It was worth mentioning that an electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 10 was used. Galvanostatic discharge-charge measurements were carried out on a LAND CT2001A battery analyzer with a voltage range between 1.5 and 2.8 V. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests (105 to 0.01 Hz) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments (1.5 to 2.8 V) were conducted on an advanced electrochemical system (CHI604E, Chenhua, Shanghai, China). The potentiostatic intermittent titration technique (PITT) test was conducted on the WonATech WBCS3000 electrochemical workstation. The cell was potentiostatically discharged from the open circuit voltage to 1.95 V, and then charged from 2.20 to 2.40 V, with intervals of 0.05 V, and each potential step lasted for 1 h. 2.7 Materials characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (H-7650, Hitachi, Japan) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Park NX10, Park systems Co., Ltd) were used to study the microstructure and morphology of MXene and MXene-APP nanosheets. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (S-4700, Hitachi, Japan) was applied to observe the morphology and element mapping of MXene, NCF, NCF-MXene, and NCF-MXene-APP. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Spectrum One, Perkin Elmer Instruments Co. Ltd) was implemented at the scanning range from 4000 to 500 cm−1 to determine the chemical structures of MXene, NCF, NCF-MXene, and NCF-MXene-APP. X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku, Japan) was carried out to investigate the phase structure of MXene and composite materials. The zeta potential was monitored using a dispersion stability test system (Brookhaven instruments, Zeta PALS). Raman spectra of various samples were recorded using a laser Raman spectrometer (Olympus, BX51). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Fisher, NEXSA) was measured to analyze the surface compositions and chemical states of the materials. UV-vis spectra of the polysulfide adsorption tests were executed via a UV-vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, UV-2550) with a wavelength range from 300 to 450 nm. Microcombustion calorimeter (MCC) (Fire Testing Technology, FTT0001) tests were performed to evaluate the flame retardancy of various samples. Infrared thermal imaging pictures were captured by a thermal imaging camera (FLIR ONE Pro). The amount of MXene/APP in the NCF-MXene-APP and the sulfur content in the NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathode were assessed via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a TA SDT Q600 instrument under air and N2 atmosphere, respectively. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured by the micromeritics ASAP 2020. 2.8 Polysulfide adsorption tests Polysulfide adsorption tests were carried out on a glass container filled with an Li2S6 solution. The 0.5 M Li2S6 solutions were prepared using the same procedure as for the catholyte except without LiTFSI and LiNO3. The NCF, NCF-MXene, and NCF-MXene-APP samples were soaked overnight in 5 mL of the Li2S6 (diluted to 5 mM) solution, and the color change of the solution was observed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication and structural characterizations of the NCF-MXene-APP host As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the NCF-MXene-APP host was prepared through an ingenious method, which involved the exfoliation of MXene nanosheets, electrostatic self-assembly process, MF carbonization treatment, and dip-coating step. The Ti3C2T x MXene shows 2D nanosheet morphology with a lateral size of 1–2 μm and a thickness of ∼5 nm. It possesses a sheet-like structure that was fabricated by etching Ti3AlC2 in a LiF/HCl solution, followed by low-power ultrasonic delamination (Fig. S1) [59]. MXene sheets carry negative surface charges due to the ionization of the hydroxyl, oxygen, and fluorine functional groups, enabling their excellent electrostatic self-assembly ability with positively charged APP particles [60,61]. The as-prepared MXene-APP suspension was dip-coated onto the carbonized NCF framework to ensure the adsorption of MXene-APP on the surface of the interconnected 3D network through electrostatic, coordination bonding, and hydrogen bonding interactions, resulting in the formation of NCF-MXene-APP during the drying process [53]. The resultant freestanding electrode loaded with the Li2S6 catholyte exhibited several advantages for Li-S batteries (Fig. 1b). First, the 3D porous framework of the NCF-MXene-APP hybrid provided ample space for sulfur species and facilitated the charge transport, which enhanced the energy density of the Li-S batteries with binder or current collector free. Second, MXene nanosheets showed excellent absorption and catalytic effects on polysulfide conversion, which promoted the efficient conversion of solid sulfur species to soluble polysulfides during electrochemical reactions [62]. In addition, the incorporation of APP onto MXene further improved chemical anchoring that confined the sulfur-active materials [52]. Moreover, the electrodes exhibited significantly improved heat resistance and flame retardancy, which are important features for designing highly safe Li-S batteries. To thoroughly investigate and confirm the possible interactions between MXene nanosheets and APP molecules (Fig. 1a), various characterization methods were conducted. Fig. 2 (a) showed a comparison of the dispersion stability of various materials in water. Water-soluble APP was easily dissolved in water because of its low degree of polymerization (Fig. 2a, left vial). MXene nanosheets could be stably dispersed in water owing to their hydrophilic surface and their repulsion forces between the MXene nanosheets (Fig. 2a, middle vial). However, when APP was added to the MXene solution, it was attracted to the surface of the MXene nanosheets. As a result, aggregation and sedimentation phenomena occurred overnight, even with a 1:2 ratio of APP to MXene (Fig. 2a, right vial), indicating the successful self-assembly between APP and MXene. Zeta potential tests were conducted to investigate the surface charge of APP, MXene, and MXene-APP in an aqueous solution and confirm their charge states. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the pure APP suspension had a zeta potential of +6.32 mV. In contrast, the MXene nanosheet was negatively charged with a zeta potential of −46.94 mV owing to surface functional groups, such as –O, –OH, and –F [63]. The zeta potential of MXene-APP was −35.83 mV, which positively shifted compared with MXene, indicating charge neutralization between positive and negative charges [64]. These results further confirmed the electrostatic self-assembly of APP with MXene nanosheets. Meanwhile, owing to the polyphosphate anions and ammonium cations of APP and the –OH or Ti group/element of MXene, coordination and hydrogen bonds were formed at both the interlayers and edges of the MXene flakes, producing a uniform distribution of N and P elements, as shown in Fig. 2(c). Consequently, an interconnected network was formed, providing substantial channels between the galleries of adjacent MXene nanosheets for the adsorption of soluble polysulfides and electron transport. The surface morphology and structural features of NCF-MXene-APP and other control samples were characterized using SEM and TEM (Fig. 2d–f and Figs. S5 and S6). The NCF showed a 3D network structure with a smooth surface and interconnected pores ranging from several to tens of micrometers (Fig. S5a). Therefore, MXene nanosheets could be distributed between the network structures and tightly wrapped on the NCF skeleton surface (Fig. S5b). After coating the MXene-APP mixture, the NCF-MXene-APP hybrids maintained the same porous structure as the pure NCF, while exhibiting a relatively rough surface. This unique structural feature facilitated the accommodation of a substantial amount of sulfur, enabling high sulfur loading and providing fast transport channels for electrons and lithium ions. Furthermore, high-magnification SEM and corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) mapping images provided direct evidence that MXene-APP was well attached to the surface of NCF frameworks, even after the ultrasonic treatment, which demonstrated the excellent structural stability for subsequent charge/discharge cycles (Fig. S7). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms indicated that the porosity of NCF-MXene-APP is reduced compared to NCF sample, which is due to the coverage of the decorated MXene/APP layer. Correspondingly, the density of NCF-MXene-APP also increased (Fig. S8). FTIR, XRD, Raman, and XPS techniques were applied to gain insights into the chemical composition and interaction of the NCF-MXene-APP composite and other materials. The FTIR spectra in Fig. 2(g) showed that the stretching vibration of –OH in MXene (∼3610 cm−1) shifted to a lower wavenumber (∼3592 cm−1) in NCF-MXene-APP, indicating the existence of hydrogen bonding between MXene nanosheets and APP molecules [65]. Besides, the NH4 + peak of APP was redshifted from 3223 to 3157 cm−1 when APP was combined with MXene, further confirming the electrostatic interaction [53]. The characteristic peaks at 1494 and 1046 cm−1 corresponded to the C=N and C–O stretching vibrations of NCF, respectively. The characteristic peak at 1072 cm−1 was attributed to the P–O symmetry vibration of APP, and the characteristic peak at 565 cm−1 corresponded to the Ti–O stretching vibrations of MXene. These peaks also appeared in the FTIR spectrum of NCF-MXene-APP [57,66]. The XPS survey spectra (Fig. S9) further verified the existence of multiple interactions in the NCF-MXene-APP. As shown in Fig. S9(a), full-scan XPS spectra distinctly revealed the coexistence of Ti, C, P, N, O, and F elements in NCF-MXene-APP. The Ti x O y 2p 3/2 and Ti–X 2p 3/2 peaks of NCF-MXene-APP shifted to lower binding energies, namely from 458.1 to 457.6 eV and 456.8 to 456.4 eV, respectively, in comparison with those of MXene. These synchronously decreased binding energies indicated the existence of P–O–Ti coordination bonding between phosphates and Ti atoms (Fig. S9b and c and Table S1) [53]. The XRD results provided additional evidence. As shown in Fig. 2(h), the interlayer spacing of NCF-MXene composite (∼1.37 nm at 6.44°) increased compared with that of the Ti3C2T x MXene (∼1.27 nm at 6.95°, which was ascribed to the (002) plane) owing to the 3D framework that effectively inhibited MXene nanosheet aggregation [67]. Moreover, the interlayer spacing value of NCF-MXene-APP further increased (∼1.42 nm at 6.30°), which was attributed to the presence of intercalated APP molecules among the MXene layers. In addition, two broad peaks at 22.55° and 44.20° corresponding to the (002) and (110) diffraction of the NCF carbon materials, respectively, were also observed in NCF-MXene-APP, implying the successful preparation of the composites [57]. The Raman spectra (Fig. 2i) revealed two broad bands at 1368 and 1570 cm−1, which corresponded to defective carbon and graphitic carbon characteristics, respectively [57]. Furthermore, several peaks derived from MXene appeared in the range of 250–750 cm−1, indicating the presence of MXene in the NCF-MXene-APP composite [68]. The I D/I G ratio values of NCF-MXene-APP and NCF-MXene were lower than that of NCF, which can be attributed to the increased ordering of the sp 2 graphitic domains in MXene, indicating higher conductivity [54]. It was conducive to the fast electron transfer during the electrochemical reaction. The above results proved that the successful preparation of NCF-MXene-APP composites with excellent physical and chemical characteristics for use as self-supporting host materials. 3.2 Binding of polysulfides with MXene-APP In order to elucidate the interaction mechanism of LiPSs with MXene-APP, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to determine adsorption energies of Li2S n species, for which n = 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 were used as representatives, on MXene and MXene-APP (Figs. S10 and S11 and Fig. 3 a). It was worth noting that the weak adsorption of NCF and Li2S n species was negligible [54]. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the calculated binding energies of the LiPSs for the MXene-APP (−4.40, −4.47, −3.70, −3.91, and −5.01 eV) were all stronger than those on the surface of MXene (−1.98, −2.48, −2.35, −3.46, and −3.70 eV). Therefore, these results demonstrated that the introduction of APP enhanced the binding strength between the LiPSs and MXene, which was expected to enable efficient polysulfide adsorption and suppress the polysulfide shuttling effect. The visual LiPSs adsorption experiment was performed to evaluate the affinity ability of NCF-MXene-APP to the polysulfides (inset of Fig. 3c). Equal masses of NCF, NCF-MXene, NCF-MXene-APP, and the L2S6 solution were mixed and last for 12 h. Compared with the original yellow Li2S6 solution, no obvious color change was observed for the Li2S6 solution containing NCF, while decolorization of the Li2S6 solution containing NCF-MXene was observed, especially the Li2S6 solution containing NCF-MXene-APP becoming transparent. These results indicated that the affinity of the LiPSs to NCF-MXene-APP was significantly enhanced. The strong contrast observed confirmed the vital role of MXene-APP in polysulfide adsorption. UV-vis spectra of these supernatants further indicated the reduced concentration of LiPSs in the NCF-MXene-APP samples. To quantitatively analyze the concentration of Li2S6 in these supernatants after the adsorption test, UV-vis spectrophotometry was carried out (Fig. 3c). We observed that the characteristic peak of the S6 2− species was weakened or even disappeared completely [69]. This meant that NCF-MXene-APP had an extraordinary polysulfide adsorption ability, which aligned with the results of the adsorption test. XPS results further revealed the chemical interaction of NCF-MXene-APP towards the LiPSs. The S 2p spectrum of NCF-MXene-APP after Li2S6 adsorption proved the existence of polythionate, thiosulfate, bridging sulfur (SB 0), and terminal sulfur (ST −1) (Fig. 3d) [36]. Notably, the emergence of thiosulfate as a sulfur oxidized species suggested that NCF-MXene-APP contributed to the redox kinetics to form polythionate. In the Ti 2p spectrum, a characteristic peak at 455.7 eV represented the Ti–S bond, which indicated the Ti–S interaction between MXene and the polysulfides (Fig. 3e) [36,70]. Meanwhile, TiO2 nanoparticles generated from oxidized MXene also enhance the adsorption/catalysis of polysulfides, thus mitigating the “shuttle effect”. As shown in Fig. 3(f and g), all the binding energies of NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 shifted to lower values compared with those of NCF-MXene-APP in both the N 1s and P 2p spectra, which proved that there were strong interactions between NCF-MXene-APP and the LiPSs. Based on this analysis and discussion, a possible mechanism for the suppression of the polysulfide shuttling effect is illustrated in Fig. 3(h). Unlike the bare MXene surface with a limited polysulfide-fixation ability, the introduction of APP on MXene exhibited significantly stronger chemisorption. Such MXene-APP nanohybrids could play an important role in effectively suppressing the shuttling effect of polysulfides. As a result, excellent long-term cycling performances and rate capabilities are achieved and will be demonstrated by the electrochemical results. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries assembled with NCF-MXene-APP hosts The electrochemical properties of NCF, NCF-MXene, and NCF-MXene-APP added with the Li2S6 catholyte were systematically investigated in Li-S batteries. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the CV curves of these cells exhibited a typical redox reaction process. Two reduction peaks at approximately 2.30 V (point A) and 1.98 V (point B) were attributed to the formation of LiPSs, while the oxidation peak at approximately 2.5 V (point C) corresponded to the conversion from LiPSs to sulfur [71]. The NCF-MXene-APP-based batteries exhibited stable CV curves over multiple cycles, indicating excellent electrochemical reversibility (Fig. S12). Moreover, compared with the NCF and NCF-MXene cells, the NCF-MXene-APP cells exhibited the lowest ΔV value between points B and C and the largest current at points A, B, and C (Fig. S13), suggesting the improved redox reaction kinetics and Li-ion transport after the introduction of MXene-APP [35]. To verify this, the diffusion coefficient of Li+ was calculated using the Randles-Sevcik equation [26]. The results showed that the battery with NCF-MXene-APP exhibited a considerably higher Li+ diffusion coefficient than the batteries with NCF and NCF-MXene throughout the redox reaction stages of S8 → Li2S4, Li2S4 → Li2S, and Li2S → S8 (Fig. 4b and Table S2) [72], which can be ascribed to the strong chemical interaction between MXene-APP and LiPSs. PITT tests were measured to further reveal the redox kinetics of lithium polysulfide using NCF-MXene-APP, NCF-MXene, and NCF hosts. (Fig. S14). The current bumps represent Li2S nucleation and decomposition process. The Li2S nucleation and decomposition peak response times of NCF-MXene-APP (187.3 min; 142.7 min) are both better than those of NCF-MXene (190.8 min; 145.1 min) and NCF (193.7 min; 146.5 min). The results imply that the NCF-MXene-APP is in favor of expediting the lithium polysulfide redox kinetics. Furthermore, EIS measurements and equivalent circuit fittings directly revealed the charge-transfer resistance values, namely 76.3, 35.03, and 31.3 Ω, of Li-S batteries with NCF, NCF-MXene, and NCF-MXene-APP, respectively (Fig. 4c). The lowest resistance value in the NCF-MXene-APP-based cell indicated that the highly conductive MXene-APP could enhance the conductivity of sulfur as well as electron and ion transport kinetics, thereby promoting the electrochemical reaction. The rate capabilities of NCF-MXene-APP and various cathodes were shown in Fig. 4(d). It could be seen that the cells made with NCF-MXene-APP delivered a high initial capacity of 1191.6, 920.6, 755.0, and 575.3 mA h g−1 at current rates of 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C, respectively, exhibiting superior rate performances to cells made with NCF and NCF-MXene. In addition, the cell with NCF-MXene-APP host exhibited a preferable reversible capacity of 1194.7 mA h g−1 when the current rate was restored to 0.2 C. Meanwhile, the constant-current charge-discharge profiles at 0.2 C were presented in Fig. 4(e) and showed that the NCF-MXene-APP-based battery had a smaller polarization potential (ΔE = 122 mV) than NCF-MXene-based (ΔE = 161 mV) and NCF-based batteries (ΔE = 208 mV), which verified the improvement in energy conversion efficiency. It should be noted that even at high current rates, two distinct discharge plateaus were still observed, indicating excellent catalytic effect of MXene and high sulfur utilization (Fig. S15). The long-cycle performance of the cells at 0.5 C was tested as shown in Fig. 4(f). A comparison of the results of NCF and NCF-MXene revealed that NCF-MXene-APP achieved the optimum result of maintaining a favorable capacity of 897.2 mA h g−1 with an inappreciable average capacity decay of 0.09% after 100 cycles. Besides, the stable structure of NCF-MXene-APP can be further confirmed via SEM observation. After the 100th cycle at 0.5 C, structural integrity of NCF-MXene-APP in the battery can still be well maintained (Fig. S16). Moreover, the NCF-MXene-APP-based cells with different sulfur loading were assembled and then tested at 1 C. As shown in Fig. S17, stable cycling was achieved at high initial-areal capacities of 3.47, 4.51, and 4.53 mA h cm−2 with sulfur loading of 3.2, 5.1, and 6,4 mg cm−2, respectively. To further evaluate the application potential, an areal capacity-sulfur loading chart was plotted based on other reported studies with high sulfur loading (Fig. 4g), as summarized in Table S3. Our as-prepared NCF-MXene-APP-based batteries were comparable to current commercial Li-ion batteries and exhibited a superior electrochemical performance to most other reports. In addition, after long-term cycling of 280 cycles at a current density of 2 C, the average capacity fading rate of the NCF-MXene-APP-based cell was as low as 0.12% per cycle (Fig. 4h), which is superior to that of the NCF-MXene-based cell (Fig. S18). Based on the above results, it was concluded that the capacity increase and capacity retention in Li-S batteries can be attributed to the NCF-MXene-APP framework that not only accelerated the interfacial charge transport and improved the loading and utilization of active materials but also enhanced the capture and conversion of polysulfides. 3.4 Safety of the Li-S batteries with NCF-MXene-APP hosts The thermal stability of electrodes at high temperatures is crucial for battery safety and reliability. Thermographic images of NCF-MXene-APP, NCF-MXene, and MXene placed on a hot stage with different temperatures (50–300 °C) were shown in Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. S19. It could be clearly observed that all samples maintained their original size even at 300 °C, and their excellent heat-resistance was primarily due to the carbonized skeleton. Comparatively, due to the incorporation of the assembled MXene-APP layer, the NCF-MXene-APP displayed the highest temperature difference between the sample surface and the hot stage. This indicated its excellent thermal insulation performance and showed great potential in protecting the battery from high-temperature damage. To further assess the flame retardancy of the NCF-MXene-APP host upon thermal triggering, burning tests were conducted for the various hosts under an alcohol burner flame (Fig. 5b and c, Fig. S20, and Movie S1). The NCF host was ignited immediately when it came into contact with a high-temperature flame, and burned violently until completely consumed. After assembling the MXene-based layers, NCF-MXene presented a slower combustion behavior and improved flame retardancy. More importantly, the NCF-MXene-APP showed nearly nonflammable characteristics, and it exhibited better flame retardancy compared with NCF-MXene owing to the incorporation of APP. Furthermore, we conducted fire-retardant performance tests on NCF-MXene-APP, NCF-MXene, and NCF, which were taken out of the cycled Li-S batteries with the absorbed catholyte and electrolyte, respectively. The NCF, which absorbed catholyte and electrolyte, immediately ignites upon contact with a flame. Even after being removed from the flame, the NCF continues to burn, resulting in structural failure. Excitingly, the fire-retardant NCF-MXene and NCF-MXene-APP, with absorbed catholyte and electrolyte, exhibit only minor combustion. After removing the ignition source, the structure of material remains intact. Notably, the NCF-MXene-APP sample is capable of rapid self-extinguishment within 3 s, greatly enhancing the safety of the battery (Fig. S21 and Movie S2). The above results indicated that the NCF-MXene-APP host possessed heat-resistant and flame-retardant properties, which could effectively improve the safety of Li-S batteries. The ability of the battery to operate under a high-temperature environment is critical to its safety and reflects the overall performance of the battery when exposed to overheating conditions. As shown in Fig. 5(d), Li-S batteries with NCF-MXene-APP hosts exhibited better capacity reversibility than those with NCF and NCF-MXene hosts at 55 °C, which is the optimal temperature that does not damage the commercial separator, with different current rates. All the corresponding charge-discharge curves of NCF-MXene-APP-based Li-S batteries exhibited two plateaus, indicating stable electrochemical reactions even at high temperatures (Fig. 5e). Meanwhile, at elevated temperatures, the ion diffusion rate increases, leading to an acceleration of electrochemical reaction kinetics. Consequently, the round curve appeared at the second discharge plateau. Moreover, due to the thermal stability and strong interaction with LiPSs, NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 exhibited impressive cycling stability at a higher temperature of 55 °C (Fig. 5f). The NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathode exhibited a capacity retention of 91.8%, which was significantly higher than NCF-MXene-Li2S6 (74.5%) and NCF-Li2S6 (66.7%). In addition, while the Coulombic efficiency of the NCF-based battery decreased to only 82.2% after 60 cycles, the NCF-MXene and NCF-MXene-APP-based batteries maintained a high Coulombic efficiency of over 95%. This further illustrates the strong affinity between MXene-APP and the LiPSs, which effectively prevents its dissolution and inhibits the shuttle effect. To study the reliability of the battery for practical application in a fire environment, coin cells with the NCF and NCF-MXene-APP hosts were used as power sources to light light-emitting diode (LED) lights, and their performance was observed during a fire attack. As shown in Fig. 5(g and h), when exposed to a flame attack for 10 s, the LED light powered by the NCF-based battery could not be illuminated. Subsequently, the battery experienced a severe explosion and continued to burn. The LED light powered by the NCF-MXene-APP-based battery did not significantly change when exposed to a flame attack for 20 s, confirming that the NCF-MXene-APP-based battery can function normally during the early stage of the fire disaster. Importantly, when the battery failed, it only exploded slightly and self-extinguished quickly (Movie S3). Overall, designing NCF-MXene-APP hosts with heat resistance and flame retardancy was of great significance for reducing the safety hazards associated with Li-S batteries. To further understand the inherent mechanism of NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathodes operating normally under a high-temperature flame, the coin cell was disassembled after being exposed to a flame attack, and the morphological structure of the cathode was analyzed (Fig. 6 a). The NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathode maintained its initial 3D network structure. In addition, the elemental mapping images of C, Ti, N, P, S, O, and F confirmed the uniform distribution of MXene-APP in the NCF-MXene-APP framework. In particular, the EDS results showed that sulfur was retained in the electrode because of the protective MXene-APP layer that prevented sulfur combustion. The MCC results provided more critical information on the combustion behavior of the electrodes (Table S4). The presence of MXene and APP on the surface of the NCF framework significantly decreased the heat release rates (HRR, 86.72 W g−1) and total heat releases (THR) of the electrodes (5.36 KJ g−1) (Fig. 6b and c). The XPS results showed the decreased intensities of the N 1s and P 2p signals after burning, indicating the decomposition of APP (Fig. 6d). When comparing the C 1s, Ti 2p, P 2p, and S 2p results before and after combustion of the NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 cathode, the formation of C–O–C, P–N, and P–C–N and the increased ratio of TiO2 revealed the formation of a cross-linked TiO2/polymer char layer on the surface of the electrode after combustion. The S 2p signal is only slightly attenuated, and polythionate, thiosulfate, SB 0, and ST −1 were still remained (Fig. S22). This provides an evidence of the presence of a protective layer that prevents sulfur combustion after the NCF-MXene-APP-Li2S6 electrode was burned. Based on the above analysis and discussion, a schematic diagram of the flame retardancy of NCF-MXene-APP host under the thermal runaway condition of Li-S battery was shown in Fig. 6(e). Under elevated operating temperature conditions, the heat-resistant and thermally-insulated NCF-MXene-APP host retarded the diffusion of external temperature into the interior of the battery, preventing the rapid accumulation of internal heat. The chemical interaction between NCF-MXene-APP and LiPSs inhibited the shuttle effect. In addition, the flame-retardant properties of the NCF-MXene-APP host prevented sulfur actives combustion by forming a cross-linked TiO2/polymer barrier when the battery was exposed to fire. Specifically, during the combustion process, APP acted as a char promoter that facilitated the formation of a carbonaceous substance, leading to a highly dense carbon layer. The thermal oxidation behavior of Ti3C2T x nanosheets resulted in the formation of TiO2 nanoparticles on the carbon layer, endowing the hybrid protective layer with the ability to inhibit mass and heat transfer [73]. In addition, APP released phosphorus-containing radicals (such as PO• and PO2•) to trap hydrogen-containing radicals (such as H• and HO•) and release nonflammable gases (such as NO and NO2), which improved the fire safety of the electrodes [74]. Overall, the comprehensive performance of the NCF-MXene-APP host indicates its potential application in high-performance and high-safe Li-S batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, self-supported MXene-APP decorated carbon foam composites with heat-resistance, thermal insulation, and flame-retardancy were successfully fabricated via a facile coating and heat treating method. The NCF-MXene-APP as strong polysulfide anchoring for Li-S battery addressed unstable electrochemical performance issues caused by the polysulfide shuttle effect and safety concerns arising from the high flammability of sulfur. As a result, the NCF-MXene-APP-based Li-S batteries exhibited excellent electrochemical performance in terms of their discharge capacity, rate capacity, and long-term cycling stability even at high sulfur loading. More importantly, these batteries demonstrated the ability to operate efficiently at an elevated temperature and resisted flame attack without fire or explosion. Therefore, this advanced multifunctional electrode composite reported herein will provide a rational design for the development of high-performance Li-S batteries and hold promise for achieving safe and durable operation in next-generation energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are one of the most promising modern-day energy supply systems because of their high theoretical energy density and low cost. However, the development of high-energy density Li-S batteries with high loading of flammable sulfur faces the challenges of electrochemical performance degradation owing to the shuttle effect and safety issues related to fire or explosion accidents. In this work, we report a three-dimensional (3D) conductive nitrogen-doped carbon foam supported electrostatic self-assembled MXene-ammonium polyphosphate (NCF-MXene-APP) layer as a heat-resistant, thermally-insulated, flame-retardant, and freestanding host for Li-S batteries with a facile and cost-effective synthesis method. Consequently, through the use of NCF-MXene-APP hosts that strongly anchor polysulfides, the Li-S batteries demonstrate outstanding electrochemical properties, including a high initial discharge capacity of 1191.6 mA h g−1, excellent rate capacity of 755.0 mA h g−1 at 1 C, and long-term cycling stability with an extremely low-capacity decay rate of 0.12% per cycle at 2 C. More importantly, these batteries can continue to operate reliably under high temperature or flame attack conditions. Thus, this study provides valuable insights into the design of safe high-performance Li-S batteries.
